-Jane

message.div: then perhaps the best place to put that listener IS in the directive
you would pass the model into the directive
and then the directive's scope would listen for changes
this would be especially good to do because it makes your dom easier to test (expected) but also it leaves the controller as the overload that does nothing but manages which things go where

div.span: oh man griffin is going to hate this

cause it's much harder to style

message.div: the style just is more element-specific
what I'm doing is having a directory structure that looks like this
but the structure I use looks like this

sampleapp/
app.css
app.js
app-controller.js
app-controller_test.js
components/
bar/ "bar" describes what the service does
bar.js
bar-service.js
bar-service_test.js
foo/ "foo" describes what the directive does
foo.js
foo-directive.js
foo-directive_test.js
index.html
for us — css is going into the component subfolder
so each component gets it's own a css style
then at compile time it's all bundled up
just how it works and stuff!
that's where you're supposed to post stuff like "so and so is coming over"
so that you don't alarm anyone
then after a while it just happens
but it's because alex is a bit of a micromanager — but not in a terrible way.
the "people over" one is because of the morning schedule
when there is a line for the bathroom or something, cause people have to go to work
